context_evidences: - The LGBTQ Nation article even pointed out that someone made a fake Washington Post story about Chewston, attributing it to Lorenz who wrote an article unmasking Chaya Raichik, the woman behind influential anti-LGBTQ+ Twitter account “Libs of TikTok.” The investigation made Lorenz the target of right-wing critics. One of them was Pushaw, who followed "Libs of TikTok." Reference: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/washington-post-dog-homophobia-article/ published on 2022-05-17 02:33:34

- On August 14th, Twitter user@kuroufo posted a blank template of the dog, writing, "what a nice looking dog. i wonder what its opinions on gay people are," referencing the meme, gaining over 34,000 likes and 3,600 retweets in seven months (shown below, left). That day, Twitter user @swolepepe commented with a photoshop of the dog changing the caption to, "I'm fond of gay people," gaining over 1,600 likes in the same span of time (shown below, right). Reference: https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/homophobic-dog-not-too-fond-of-gay-people published on 2022-03-15 13:44:54

- On March 13th, Twitter user @scrimblopilled posted, "the owners of the homophobic dog are gay im crying," along with an image of the dog with her owners, a gay couple, gaining over 33,000 likes in two days (shown below, right). Reference: https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/homophobic-dog-not-too-fond-of-gay-people published on 2022-03-15 13:44:54

- The fake screenshot likely originated from a meme featuring the real-life dog Whitney Chewston. An article on LGBTQ Nation from May 16, 2022, carried the headline, “This dog is the new face of online homophobia.” Reference: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/washington-post-dog-homophobia-article/ published on 2022-05-17 02:33:34
correction_response:
This tweet is misinformed. The article claiming that a dachshund has become a viral homophobic meme is not real. The screenshot of the supposed Washington Post article went viral, but it's fake. Taylor Lorenz, who was falsely credited as the author, denied writing it. The meme featuring the dog, Whitney Chewston, originated as an inside joke among friends in the LGBTQ+ community. The trend of ironic homophobic memes featuring this dog was started by Twitter user @yolanda_parody. 

References:
https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/washington-post-dog-homophobia-article/
https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/homophobic-dog-not-too-fond-of-gay-people
note_1_text: On May 16th, Taylor Lorenz shared an Instagram post that read, "200k likes and I'll actually write this fake story," but she did not write the story: https://www.instagram.com/p/CdoYgCwvPh-/    A real story with the same headline appeared on May 16th in LGBTQ Nation: https://www.lgbtqnation.com/2022/05/dog-new-face-online-homophobia/
note_2_text: This is a real story. But it was not written by Taylor Lorenz nor was it published in The Washington Post.     The story was actually published by a different writer on the website LGBTQNation.     https://www.lgbtqnation.com/2022/05/dog-new-face-online-homophobia/
queries:
1. "Internet trolls turned dachshund into homophobic meme" article by Taylor Lorenz
2. "Dachshund viral homophobic meme May 13, 2022"
3. "Taylor Lorenz article on homophobic meme featuring a dachshund"
4. "Logan Hickman Instagram photo of dachshund homophobic meme"
5. "Gay owners of dachshund turned into homophobic meme"
refute_evidences: - Additional images of Whitney Chewston also became the subject of ironic homophobic memes in 2022, as well as memes suggesting the dog learned from its homophobic ways or came out as gay itself. The trend was started by Twitter user @yolanda_parody. Reference: https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/homophobic-dog-not-too-fond-of-gay-people published on 2022-03-15 13:44:54

- On an unknown date prior to March 23rd 2021, an anonymous Instagram artist created an image macro using the photo of the dog, captioned using the Whisper app, "not too fond of gay people" (shown below, left). This was confirmed by Know Your Meme through a DM with Whitney's owners. Apparently, the user, a member of the LGBTQ+ community, made the meme to use amongst friends as an inside joke. Reference: https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/homophobic-dog-not-too-fond-of-gay-people published on 2022-03-15 13:44:54

- A screenshot of a supposed Washington Post article headlined, “This dog is the new face of online homophobia,” with a photograph of a dog, went viral in the spring of 2022. But the article is not real. Reference: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/washington-post-dog-homophobia-article/ published on 2022-05-17 02:33:34

- Lorenz denied writing the article. She also joked that she would write it if it would "get me to 500k followers". Reference: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/washington-post-dog-homophobia-article/ published on 2022-05-17 02:33:34
tweet_image2text: An article claiming, "Internet trolls have turned a dachshund into a viral homophobic meme - and her gay owners don't know what to do." It attached a picture of a dachshund with a caption that reads, "This dog is the new face of online homophobia." It was written by Taylor Lorenz and published on May 13, 2022 at 5:05 p.m. EDT. The photo was credited to Logan Hickman/Instagram.
